history.provenance: 'Sum Johannis Gibbon. e coll. sancte et individuae Trinitatis Oxon : et ejusdem coll. convictoris. Anno Domini 1628 men: Maij nono' (fol. 72v).

recordHist.source:
Summary description by Elizabeth Solopova and Matthew Holford, based on the Watson, Pächt and Alexander, and the Quarto Catalogue (W. H. Black, A descriptive, analytical, and critical catalogue of the manuscripts bequeathed unto the University of Oxford by Elias Ashmole Esq...., Quarto Catalogues X, 1845) and supplementary sources; additional description of decoration by Elizabeth Solopova, c. 2000.
Quarto Catalogue, cols. 313-14 Quarto Catalogue, cols. 315-6 Quarto Catalogue, col. 317 Summary Catalogue, vol. 2, part 2, p. 1118 Summary Catalogue, vol. 2, part 2, p. 1125 Summary Catalogue, vol. 2, part 2, p. 1143

listBibl.bibl: A. G. Watson, Catalogue of Dated and Datable Manuscripts c.435-1600 in Oxford Libraries (Oxford, 1984), no. 35
Otto Pächt and J. J. G. Alexander, Illuminated Manuscripts in the Bodleian Library Oxford, III (1973), nos. 442, 472

msItem.title: De physiognomia
msItem.incipit: Ex tribus auctoribus quorum libros
msItem.explicit: pronus ad libidinem studiosus pantominorum et maledicus
msItem.finalRubric: explicit phisonomia. anno iesu christi Milesimo. centesimo. lii.
msItem.note: Ed. R. Foerster, Scriptores physiognomonici, II (1893), 3-145, collated as MS. A; here ending at p. 128 (c. 104) 'effrenati sunt', followed by c. 103 (p. 126).

msItem.title: Medical recipes
msItem.note: Added, c. 1300, in probably three hands: (a) items i, ii (b) item iii (c) item iv

msItem.incipit: Ad probandum utrum mulȝer fuerit uȝrgo R. lipitum
Ad coigulandum lic R. folȝi
Ad lepram puluis puluerizetur radix draganti
Vngues remoueantur cum riȝi cocto in aceto fortissimo emplaustrato

msItem.note: Full page diagram (see decoration) with texts added in some of the empty space.

msItem.incipit: Si in partu laborat mulier da diptanni cum appozimate fenugreci
Nota quod Henricus de parci curatus est de lapide per solam hasti regie aquam
Ruta a proprietate contra (?)
Experimentum quod nunquam fallit et hoc quando dubitacio fit an culpa fit ex parte viri an mulieris proueniat inpedimentum
msItem.explicit: circa collum habeat dum femina congnoscit
msItem.note: Cf. Gilbert Anglicus, Compendium seu Lilium medicinae (Lyons, 1510), f. 287r; C. Rider, Magic and Impotence in the Middle Ages (Oxford, 2006), p. 164 n. 14.

msItem.author: Muscio
msItem.title: Gynaecia
msItem.incipit: Si in pedibus descendit
msItem.note: Ten foetus-in-utero illustrations with accompanying text, a section of Muscio's text which circulated independently; M. Green, Women's Healthcare in the Medieval West (Ashgate, 2000), appendix pp. 21-22, with references.

msItem.author: Constantinus Africanus
msItem.title: De genitalibus membris
msItem.incipit: Matrix in forma sua est est ad modum vesice
msItem.note: Siglum A ('a poor text riddled with careless errors') in M. Green, 'The De genecia Attributed to Constantine the African', Speculum 62 (198), 299-323 (at 312-23). Incomplete, text breaks off at ed. cit. l. 141 (p. 319).

msItem.title: Chiromantic text
msItem.note: Pr. from Cambridge, Trinity College, MS. R.17.1 (the Eadwine psalter) by C. S. F. Burnett, 'The earliest chiromancy in the West', Journal of the Warburg and Courtauld Institutes 50 (1987), 189-95 (at 192-5)
'Fünfbildserie': full page anatomical diagrams (drawings and wash) of male figures, with explanatory text on the facing verso (text facing fol. 18r missing due to a missing folio before fol. 18).

msItem.author: Constantinus Africanus
msItem.title: De coitu
msItem.finalRubric: Explicit liber de cohitu constant. Deo gratias.

msItem.title: Trotula
msItem.incipit: Cum auctor vniuersitatis deus in prima mundi origine rerum naturas singulas iuxta genus suum distingueret

msItem.title: De spermate
msItem.note: V. Tavone Pasaalacqua, Microtegni seu de spermate. Traduzione e commento, Corpus scriptorum medicorum infimae latinitatis et prioris medii aevi, ed. Adalberto Pazzini, I, Rome 1958, pp. 227-306

msItem.author: Ricardus Anglicus
msItem.title: Anatomia
msItem.incipit: Galieno testante in tegni
msItem.explicit: et inde nutrimentum omnium membrorum habent sic nil omissum
msItem.note: Siglum A in K. Sudhoff, ed. 'Der 'Micrologus'-text der 'Anatomia' Richards des Engländers', Archiv für Geschichte der Medizin 19 (1927), 209-39 (at 212-34)

msItem.author: Constantinus Africanus
msItem.title: De stomacho
msItem.note: E. Montero Cartelle, ed. Liber Constantini De stomacho: El tratado ‘Sobre el estómago’ de Constantino el Africano. Estudio, edición critica y traducción (Valladolid: Ediciones Universidad de Valladolid, 2016) [not seen]

msItem.author: Johannes de Sancto Paulo
msItem.title: De simplicium medicinarum uirtutibus
msItem.finalRubric: Explicit liber de simplici medicinia editus a magistro Johanne de sancto Paulo deo gratias amen

msItem.title: Quid pro quo
msItem.incipit: Cum ea que sunt utilia in curis omnibus inueniri non possunt

msItem.author: Iohannes Platearius
msItem.title: Practica brevis
msItem.incipit: Apoplexia est opilatio omnium ventriculorum cerebri

msItem.author: Giles of Corbeil
msItem.title: De urinis
msItem.incipit: Dicitur urina quoniam sit renibus una
msItem.explicit: Fimbria monstretur quam non est tangere dignus
msItem.note: L. Choulant Aegidii Corboliensis Carmina medica (Leipzig, 1826), pp. 1-18

msItem.rubric: Titulus liber hic instabilis hic incipit an tibi penis An sors instabilis melius foret ars docet eius

msItem.incipit: In septem stabulis
msItem.note: Regula I D (Burnett, p. 112), omitting l. 3.

msItem.incipit: De vita Quid erit Dic Quere A Sedente super Orientalem facitem turris Saturni
msItem.explicit: Prima redi responde perge ad iudicem fatorum algaganar xxviii

msItem.incipit: Hoc ornamentum decus est et fama parentum retentum
msItem.explicit: Vita solamen cupis hoc tibi deus amen
msItem.note: Text, second version, Thorndike-Kibre 633E; unprinted. Lacks responses 9-24, implying four folios of text missing between fols. 57v and 58r.

msItem.title: Onomantic text ('Victor and vanquished')
msItem.incipit: .i. .i. minor vincet
msItem.note: Cf. Burnett's Associated tract 1; cf. C. Burnett, 'The Eadwine psalter and the Western tradition of the onomancy in Pseudo-Aristotle's Secret of Secrets, Archives d'Histoire Doctrinale et Littéraire du Moyen Âge, 55 (1988), 143-67, text B (pp. 154-5)

msItem.title: Text on chiromancy
msItem.incipit: Tres sunt linee naturales omnes omnis chyros

msItem.author: Philaretus
msItem.title: Liber pulsuum
msItem.note: Pr. in Articella seu Opus artis medicinae (Venice, 1483; ISTC ia01143000)
msItem.incipit: Intencionem habemus in presenti conscripcione
Pvulsus est mocio cordis et arteriarum que secundum diastolem et sistolem
msItem.finalRubric: Explicit liber de pulsibus qui scripsit sit benedictus

msItem.title: Trotula
msItem.note: Extracts from De ornatu mulierum; added, early 14th century.

msItem.incipit: Si fuerit fetor oris causi stomachi et interiorum
Si habuit mulier os fetens causa putridinis
msItem.explicit: de rosis et cynamomo facto super aspergat

msItem.author: Alexander de Villa Dei
msItem.title: Algorismus
msItem.note: Ed. R. Steele, The earliest arithmetics in English, London, 1922, pp. 72-80. The section on multiplication (from 'Articulum si per reliquum uis multiplicare', l. 143, to 'Multiplicandorum de normis sufficient hec', l. 174) here comes at the end of the text, as in some other manuscripts (e.g. Cambridge, Trinity College, MS. O.2.45).

msItem.author: Johannes de Sacro Bosco
msItem.title: Algorismus
msItem.note: Lacks ch. 11 of the printed text
msItem.incipit: Omnia que a primeua mundi origine processerunt racione numerorum formata sunt
msItem.explicit: aliquid addere per modum addicionis et redibunt eedem

decoDesc.decoNote: Fine historiated diagrams, borders. Good miniatures (coloured marginal drawings), initials. (P&A iii. 472, pl. XLVI)
Coloured drawings, coloured initials, rubrics.
(fol. 1r), miniature: seated figure in physician's cap. Figure in long robe pointing to the text.
(fol. 13v), miniature: diagram showing female reproductive organs, including womb with foetus inside.
(fols. 14r-15r), miniature: drawings showing different positions of a child in the womb.
(fol. 17r), miniature: chiromantic drawing of the left and right hand.
(fol. 18r), miniature: drawing of human body showing veins.
(fol. 19r), miniature: drawing of human body showing arteries.
(fol. 20r), miniature: drawing of human body showing bones.
(fol. 21r), miniature: drawing of human body showing nerves.
(fol. 22r), miniature: drawing of human body showing muscles.
(fol. 22v), miniature: diagramatic representaion of excretory system.
(fol. 23r), miniature: stomach, kidneys and liver.
(fol. 23v), miniature: internal organs.
(fol. 24r), miniature: internal organs, including intestines.
(fol. 24v), miniature: male reproductive organs.

history.provenance: A table showing lunar cycles, dominical letters, and Easter Days on fols. 25-9 begins a continuous year-by-year table from 1292 on fol. 25v, which suggests that c. 1292 was the year of writing. The date probably covers the whole volume, certainy fols. 1-63, excepting fols. 33-34 (part 2), and the 14th-century additions (see below).
Added medieval recipes, 14th century, beginning, fols. 46c, 47r-v, 52v-53r.

decoDesc.decoNote: Good miniatures (coloured drawings). (P&A iii. 442, pl. XL)
(fol. 33r), miniature: a female patient is swooning, supported on either side by a female figure. Little dog lies asleep at the lady's side. Physician, holding a scroll and a monk stand beside.

(fol. 33v), miniature: a female patient lies on bed with a bowl (perhaps of holy water) over her heart. Two tall candles in candlesticks stand to the rigth of the bed. Attendants, standing by woman's head, implore phisician's aid. A child, kneeling in front of the bed, lifts hands towards the phisician, imploringly. Physician, stands at the foot of the bed, holding a scroll with his left hand, and lifting up the patient's hand with his right hand. Besides him stand a surgeon, and four other figures. Crowing cocks decorate the upper right and left corners of the page.

(fol. 33v), miniature: a female patient has partially recovered; she is standing and a vessel containing the holy water is falling from her left hand. An attendant is holding something (probably a pin rolled in wool and steeped in aromatic substance) to her nostril. A child stands by her side, but apparently swooning with relief. Physician stands beside, holding a scroll and pointing at the patiend; another male figure stands behind him.

(fol. 34r), miniature: a female patient lies on bed, draped with coverlet, head propped up on a pillow. Behind the bed stand three figures: a woman, turning imploringly to the physician, a tonsured monk, and another figure, possibly a monk. Physician, accompanied by a monk, stands at the foot of the bed. He has performed a urinoscopy, and lets a urine glass fall from his right hand, while raising his left hand and lookng warningly towards the group at the woman's bed.

(fol. 34r), miniature: a female corpse has been eviscerated; different organs lie around. At the foot of the cadaver stands the dissector with a knife in his left hand and a liver (three-lobed) in his right hand. His countenance exhibits alarm and surprise, as he is interrupted by a physician and a monk. The physician touches the disector with a warning finger, his other hand raised reproachfully.

(fol. 34v), miniature: a physician, seated in a chair, is being consulted by four female patients, standing in a queue. A male figure holding a purse, presumably collecting fees, stands at the end on the queue.

(fol. 34v), miniature: a physician, mounted on a horse and holding a hawking glove, starts to ride away. He turns back towards a group of five women, who bid him farewell. At the horse's head stands a male figure, holding a hawk. Both he and the doctor raise their fingures in admonition.
